pageContext.desc: On his tenure as Office of Indian Affairs agent to the Blackfeet, Piegan, Blood, and Gros Ventres Indians in Montana Territory.
pageContext.category: Diaries; Indians of North America; Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection

pages.transcription:
Monday, January 1st, 1855.
Blackfeet Chiefs -- 
Nee-oox-hus-tum-ak -- Three Bulls
An-ko-Mah-ki-ay - Swan
Naw-to-sah-pee - Sun
An-so-Kee-Mith-Kin - Hair Collar
Sturm - Ek-Krispee-My
Sturm - Ek-so-te-ko-py - Bull turns round

Friday June 6th 1856
Very pleasant day - 
The hunter went out hunting with two carts. -
A few Assinnboins visited the fort, they state that about one hundred lodges are camped about fifteen miles below -

Saturday, January 5th, 1856
Sudden change during the night, this morning quite warm and snow melting fast - about 12 O'clock one of the most sudden changes in the weather I ever witnessed - changing from warm and pleasant to cold and stormy all in ten minutes - 
Express left this morning -

SUNDAY, January 6th, 1856 
It continued to snow during the night and this morning the snow is about one foot deeper than yesterday morning - 
Cleared off about Eleven O'clock -

MONDAY, Jaunary 7th, 1856
Nothing occurred worthy of notice - 
Very cold and but few indians visited the fort who report several indians lost and frozen in the late storm. -

TUESDAY, January 8th, 1856
Another very cold day, clear and some wind - 
No indians visited the fort - 
Brilliant sun dogs as sun set -

WEDNESDAY, January 9th, 1856
Another cold day, the waggons have been now 73 days gone from the other Fort and fifty four from this and nothing heard from them yet -

THURSDAY, January 10th, 1856
Pleasant, mild morning but not thawing any, continued pleasant during the day - no winds

FRIDAY, January 11th 1856
Another beautiful day - thawed a very little - some "Gros Ventres" visited the fort also a war party of Blood Indians - 
The war party had three horses - one of them shod -

SATURDAY, January 12th, 1856
Beautiful day - 
Nothing doing - 
Few Indians visited the fort brought some meat -

SUNDAY, January 13th, 1856
Very pleasant - 
Thawing very little
Thermometer 34° above zero - 
"Sitting Squaw" came to the fort with meat - 
Heard Mr. May had lost one of his horses -

MONDAY, January 14th, 1856
This morning - 5° above zero at daylight - heavy white frost - 
A few Gros Ventres came to the fort, brought some meat and a few Robes -

TUESDAY, January 15th, 1856
Weather still pleasant - froze last night quite hard but thawed again today -
More Gros Ventres visited the fort -

WEDNESDAY, January 16th, 1856
Very pleasant - 
"Bearden"? a Gros Ventres visited the fort - no news from below - 
More meat in the fort than can be consumed in two months -

THURSDAY, January 17th 1856
Still clear and pleasant - no arrivals today - 
We are daily expecting to hear from below -
Shot a wood rat - singular llittle animal looks like a common rat except tail and ears - former is bushy latter very large -

FRIDAY, January 18th 1856
Very pleasant day -
About ten O'clock we heard some guns fired on the bluff and saw people coming - It proved to be an express brought dates of Sept. 10th - No particular news - Sioux war going on - 
Mr. Bird also arrived today - his son had stolen a squaw, wife of a Piegan, - her brother killed her and her husband had stolen Mr. Birds horses (27) - He came to get me to assist him in their recovery -

SATURDAY, January 19th 1856
Quite pleasant - 
Yesterday was truly a day of excitement - among the rest - Mr. May's horses were found and brought in by the Gros Ventres  
What has become of him is not known
I sent "a talk"? to the Piegan who has Mr. Bird's horses
- The express reports snow very deep and waggons still at Fort Union when he left. (Dec. 18th)

SUNDAY, January 20th 1856
A little cooler - slight flurry of snow - 
Nothing new -

MONDAY, January 21st 1856
Cool morning - cold pleasant day - 
Mr Revais with two other men started down to meet the waggons and assist them up - some Blood indians visited the fort

TUESDAY, January 22d 1856
Cold Morning - 
No indians visited us today and every thing is quiet -

WEDNESDAY, January 23d 1856
Warm + cloudy - prospect of snow - 
Commenced snowing in the afternoon and fell about two inches -
"Sitting Squaw" brought in the last of the three horses,  Mr. May started with, so that he is now on foot -

THURSDAY, January 24th 1856
Cool day - 
"Red Bull" brought in three of the horses taken from Mr. Bird, says the indian refuses to deliver up the balance -

FRIDAY, January 25th 1856
Cold - Water froze again last night in our room - 
No arrivals and no news -

SATURDAY, Jannary 26th 1856
Cold - 
No news - no indians - very lonesome - we pass the time reading and feeding our imaginations with oyster suppers +c. etc. which we will have in reality when we return to civilization -

SUNDAY, January 27th 1856
Continued cold - 
The "oldest inhabitant says there has been nothing like it for many years - 
Snow fell to the depth of two inches this afternoon - cleared off very cold in the evening

MONDAY, January 28th 1856
Tall Blackfoot visited the fort today - came with a long story from the Bloods and Blackfeet that I was going to poison them and shoot them with a big gun +c. etc.

TUESDAY, January 29th 1856
Cold but pleasant
- Big Feather, a Blood, came today also many "Gros Ventres" to trade - 
"Feather" brought me a horse which he said had been stolen from the Flat Heads - wishes me to return it to them -

WEDNESDAY, January 30th 1856
Mild and pleasant - thawed a little during the day - the head Chief of the Bloods visited the fort today - 
Three Blackfeet returned from war - saw saw Crows near -

THURSDAY, January 31st 1856
Cool Morning - a very little snow falling - 
I rode over to Mr. Clark's found them all well - 
"Middle Sitter," and "Low Horn" Piegan chiefs and "Hair Collar" Blackfoot Chief visited me

FRIDAY, February 1st 1856
Cold but pleasant
Head chief of Bloods left today after making many professions of friendship after a determination to stop the young men from going to war in future -

SATURDAY, February 2d 1856
Bright cold day - But few arrivals and little trade - 
"Bad Head" came to visit me - made a long speech - the substance of which was that he likes sugar -

SUNDAY, February 3d 1856
Cool pleasant day - 
An express arrived today for the other fort - 
Report the waggons stopped on account of snow below "Milk River" - several horses dead and the balance very poor - snow very deep - "Gros Ventres" brought in a mule which they found  - it is one of those taken down by Revais 
- The Express met May 22 days from here and not half way down

MONDAY, February 4th, 1856
Cold cloudy morning - 
No arrivals and dull as ever -

TUESDAY, February 5th, 1856
Cold - 
A few "Piegans" passed the fort moving across the rim - 
Mr. Dawsons friend came in to visit, had no robes -

WEDNESDAY, February 6th, 1856
Very cold - 
A party of Blackfeet arrived at the other fort to trade, they were much frightened by the stories they had heard of "Bad Medicine" Big guns +c. etc.  finally mustered courage to visit me during the evening - went away well pleased -

THURSDAY, February 7, 1856
Milder, but not thawing in the morning - 
-Thawed a little during the day - 
Thermometer at 28° -

FRIDAY, February 8th, 1856
Beautiful morning - 
Thermometer at forty above zero - 
Thawed very little during the day - 
A few "Gros Ventres" visited the fort to trade

SATURDAY, February 9th, 1856
Mild, Thermometer at 30 - 
"Star Robe" and other "Gros Ventres" came to trade - 
No news -

SUNDAY, February 10th, 1856
Pleasant, With wind
Thermometer at 35°- Thawing considerable -
A few "Gros Ventres" visited the fort -

MONDAY, February 11th, 1856
Very pleasant - 
Thermometer at 47° -
Thawing rapidly -
"Red Bull" a Piegan came to the fort - brough to me seven more of Mr. Birds horses -

TUESDAY, February 12th, 1856
Very pleasant - 
Thawed some in the night and the thermometer stood at 52 today - River changing its appearance and snow rapidly disappearing - 
"Feather" and "Father of all children" two Blood chiefs came to the fort today - report a large party of Blackfeet on their way -

WEDNESDAY, February 13th, 1856
Very pleasant - 
Thawing and water running on the ice - Many Piegans moving across the river, opposite the fort - 
Five young men arrived from the Blackfeet - say they will be here tomorrow or next day -

THURSDAY, February 14th, 1856
Warm - snow nearly disappeared from the prairie and river is looking badly = but indians are still crossing - 
Trade is quite brisk and all are busy but myself
Mr. Revais returned reports waggons below Milk River waiting for assistance

FRIDAY, February 15th, 1856
Warm - Snow all disappeared - 
Blackfeet arrived early - held council and made them a present - They appeared to be much pleased and say there shall be no more war - 
Mr Dawson traded five hundred robes -

SATURDAY, February 16th, 1856
Warm and the ice getting poor - 
Blackfeet left after finishing their trade - 
I rode over to Mr. Clarks found them all well - 
The man who came with the express from Ft. Union starts back tomorrow - 
Mr Dawson traded three hundred and fifty robes

SUNDAY, February 17th, 1856
Very pleasant - froze last night some - Three Men started for Fort Union today - 
Mr. Picotte started his exposes? also - 
Trade was apparently quite lively and at night Robes footed up three hundred and fifty -

MONDAY, February 18th, 1856
Light change in weather, windy and a little cooler - 
One of the Blackfeet returned with a complaint, that Gros Ventres had stolen three of his horses - 
Mr. Dawson traded 647 Robes from Gros Ventres + Piegans
"Lame Bull" remains in the fort -

TUESDAY, February 19th 1856

Very pleasant - 
Trade commenced very early in the morning - 
About 10 O'clock - a grand display of indians, firing of guns +c etc, proved to be Sitting Squaw and General's son 
- Mr. Dawson traded seven hundred and sixty five robes.

WEDNESDAY, February 20 1856
Very pleasant - 
"Two Elk" and some Piegans came to trade - The fort is full before I am up every morning and continues so during the day - 
Mr. Dawson traded 550 robes -

THURSDAY, February 21 -1856
Cloudy and somewhat cooler - 
A few Gros Ventres trading - Mr Dawson Traded two hundred and twenty five robes - river looks bad - a horse broke through the ice today

FRIDAY, February 22 1856
Very pleasant - the river opened during the night - still a little ice adhering to the shores - but we can once more see the water flowing which is quite gratifying
Mr. Dawson traded 227 Robes and I got a very fine Beaver robe

SATURDAY, February 23 1856
Chilly wind and cloudy - some Blackfeet and Piegans arrived to trade - a Blood returned from war, says the leader of the party is on his way home with eleven wounds but no horses - 
Mr. D- Dawson traded 444 Robes today -

SUNDAY, February 24 1856
Bright, pleasant day but very windy - 
"Little Dog" and band came to trade - 
"Big Eagle" a Gros Ventres brought me two fine robes - 
Mr. D- Dawson traded 249 Robes -

MONDAY, February 25th 1856
Cloudy, cool day, I bought a cart horse yesterday and today he was brought to the fort by a Piegan chief who had taken him away from a Blackfoot who had stolen him - 
Mr. Dawson traded 642 crossed out 622 Robes -
Commenced snowing in the afternoon -

TUESDAY, February 26 - 1856
Snow fell to the depth of three or four inches - 
Cloudy but snow thawing fast - 
Warparty of Bloods arrived with 8 Crow scalps report having visited the Flathead lodges and that they heard there that Gov. Stevens had been killed by the Snakes -
Mr. D- Dawson traded 322 Robes

WEDNESDAY, February 27th 1856
Cool last night - froze hard but is clear and pleasant this morning. -
Another Warparty returned yesterday - say they tried to take some White men's horses on the Yellow Stone and were driven off one received ten wounds another two - 
Mr. D- Dawson traded 212 Robes -

THURSDAY, Friday 28th 1856 -
Cool day - "Middle Sitter" arrived, he is the richest of the Piegans, has about 250 horses, some very good ones - 
Mr. D- Dawson traded 310 Robes

FRIDAY, Feby. 29th 1856
Bright, cool morning, quite windy - 
A few Indians visited the fort and some came for the purpose of trading 
- Mr. D- Dawson traded 312 Robes - 
The Gros Ventres came and tendered their services to revenge Gov. Stevens death, if it should prove true - also the Piegans -

SATURDAY, March 1st 1856
Cool and windy - 
The Piegan soldiers came to the fort to dance today - 
Nothing new to me, it is the same monotonous singing and jumping of the prairie traders generally - 
Mr. D- Dawson traded 296 Robes -

SUNDAY, March 2d 1856
Snowed very little last night - this morning cloudy but mild - 
Many Indians visited the fort - 
Heard a rumor that a Blackfoot had been killed on the Yellow Stone by the Crows - 
Mr. Dawson traded 196 Robes -

MONDAY, March 3d 1856
Cloudy and chilly - snowed a little -
Gros Ventres came to the fort to dance - 
Indian arrived from the Blood Camp with the news that a party of Crows had killed one Blackfoot and probably more will hear the news tomorrow
Mr. D- Dawson traded 160 -

TUESDAY, March 4th 1856
Cloudy - 
Many Indians visited me and among them a party of about 100 Gros Ventres soldiers came to dance - 
Mr. D- Dawson traded 346 robes -

WEDNESDAY, March 5th 1856
Cloudy with some winds - 
I am making preparations to start down tomorrow - 
Mr. Clark goes along with a band of one hundred horses - 
Mr. D- Dawson traded 410 Robes -

THURSDAY, March 6th 1856
Beautiful morning
- We started early but only came four miles and camped on the Teton River to wait for Mr. Clark, he overtook us in the afternoon and camped - 
I have with me - Mr. Wilson and two men - one cart and eight horses - 
Mr. Clark has 12 carts and 98 horses - and the men have 8 or ten more -

FRIDAY, March 7th 1856
Chilly and windy but wind upon our backs - We travelled about eight miles and camped near the crossing of the Maria - 
Gros Ventres all camped about one mile below us - 
The first shower of the season this afternoon, very slight and soon cleared up -

SATURDAY, March 8th 1856
Cloudy and cool - 
We started about eight O'clock - 
Crossed the Maria River, shook hands with all the Gros Ventres and reached the top of the hill by ten O'clock - We proceeded on over a level prairie about twelve miles and camped at the "spring" More mud hole than spring - We brought a little wood with us on the carts as there is none grows on the road until we reach the Box Elder, twenty miles further on -

TUESDAY, March 11th 1856
Cold and stormy - 
We concluded to remain in camp today on account of the weather - 
Two of the men went out and killed a fine cow and a fat Bull -

WEDNESDAY, March 12th 1856
Cold morning - 
We started early and travelled, twelve miles, to the crossing of Milk River - 
Passing thousands of Buffalo during the day - The grass is very poor, all cut off by the buffalo and our horses fare poorly - We cut down some young cotton wood trees for them -

THURSDAY, March 13th 1856
Cool morning - 
We travelled on about 15 miles - 
Passed buffalo continually, immense bands - 
Killed several - after we camped the buffalo came running towards our camp we shot three within 500 yards of the camp two fat cows and a Bull

FRIDAY, March 14th 1856
Quite cold started early, crossed one fork of Milk River - and camped immediately below it - We had met the waggons which left Fort Benton last November, they have had a hard time, lost many horses and camped out all winter - 
I procured a white Buffalo Robe from Mr. Cadotte - gave him a fine horse for it -

SATURDAY, March 15th 1856
Very pleasant day - We travelled only about ten miles - I shot a bull across the river, could not get him - saw many antelope and one band of Elks - 
The boys who were out in the prairie report having seen an Antelope with a bell on, probably lost from the Hudson Bay post -

SUNDAY, March 16th 1856
Cool day -
We travelled about fifteen miles and camped in a point of timber where there was a little grass, but it is so scarce that we are compelled to cut down young cotton wood trees for them to feed upon - 
One of the men killed an Antelope with his knife -

WEDNESDAY, March 19th 1856
We travelled today about twenty miles, crossed Milk River and camped - 
Tomorrow we have a hard day as we leave the river and make a cut off - 
We had a buffalo chase today or Mr. Clark did, my lower route not go - Mr. C- Clark killed two -

THURSDAY, March 20th 1856
We started early and crossed the "Big Bend" and camped at the "Medicine Lodge" - 
The distance, probably, about twenty miles. 
Saw many buffalo but killed none - 
Our horses get so little to eat that half a day's journey tires them more than a whole day when feed is good - 
We see a little snow occasionally, and the prairies are quite wet -

FRIDAY, March 21st 1856
Very pleasant Morning,
We made another cut off of 12 Miles, found the road very wet - Three of the men went out to hunt and killed four antelope and one Bull - They brought in the brains and we had fried brains for supper - 
The sun crosses the line today and it is the first day of spring and is truly a spring day - the warmest of the season
We crossed Milk river and camped - 
We found the river so high that we were compelled to raise the loads -

SATURDAY, March 22d 1856
Rained a very little last night - Wind blew a gale this morning
We travelled about five miles and came to a creek which was very deep and rapid - we crossed it in skins - occupied so much time that we camped immediately after we had crossed -

SUNDAY, March 23d 1856
A very pleasant day - 
It is Easter Sunday and my birthday - 
We travelled about ten miles, saw no game, one of my men killed a beaver - 
We saw a few ducks and geese flying, but the buffalo have entirely disappeared -

MONDAY, March 24 1856
Windy, cold morning and we concluded to remain in camp today some went out to hunt as we are nearly out of meat - 
The result of the hunt was one cow, two Bulls, four geese and two ducks - Geese were flying to the west in great numbers during the day - 
It rained some towards evening -

TUESDAY, March 25th 1856
It rained some during the night, but was clear this morning and quite pleasant but a strong south east wind made it rather cold for us, we travelled about two miles and came to Willow Creek found it too high to ford and went up about a mile and crossed - after going about five miles further we camped at 1/2 past two O'clock - 
It commenced raining at dark -

WEDNESDAY, March 26th 1856
Rained until about midnight and then turned to snow and this morning the ground is white - 
The sun came out warm and the snow soon disappeared - 
We travelled about ten miles and camped opposite "Tiger Butte" - 
Shucette and another man went out hunting and returned with meat - We also discovered five bulls near camp, went out and killed two, took the best parts - 
Buffalo scarce, no cows in sight for two days

THURSDAY, March 27th 1856
Strong East winds. We travelled about seven miles and camped at Porcupine River - saw may Buffalo - Man killed three cows - 
We also saw a few beaver near our camp, in the creek -
- Shucette shot a beaver about twenty yards from the lodge -

FRIDAY, March 28th 1856
Cold East winds, 
Mr. Clark had the misfortune to lose a colt that was foaled last night - 
We remained at camp today - several beaver were killed - I shot one only - 
Quite mild and pleasant in the afternoon -
The men discovered a bear on the prairie several went to kill it but did not succeed in getting it - is proved to be a female with three 3 Cubs, two of which they brought to camp - They are lively little fellows but already, though not more than a week old, begin to exhibit the ferocity of the Grizzly

SATURDAY, March 29th -1856
Wind still from the east and quite cool, but we started on and travelled about four or five miles and once more struck the Missouri, 
Buffalo plenty and deer quite numerous - We had just camped when then came up a terrible storm, snow and rain which lasted all night -

SUNDAY, March 30th 1856
Still storming, ground covered with snow, wind easterly - We did not move today - Two of the men went out - killed two Elk and two Bulls - 
- Half Breed (George) killed some ducks - 
Stormed nearly all day and no prospect of clearing up -

MONDAY, March 31st  1856
Foggy and mild - 
Rained some in the forenoon - We continued in same camp - too wet to move - 
Mr. Clark and Mr. Wilson went out hunting - Returned without having killed any thing - 
Cleared up in the afternoon -

TUESDAY, April 1st 1856
We started on - 
Pleasant day -Wind strong from the west - We travellled about four miles and crossed the "Porcupine of the Missouri" - Went about ten miles further and camped - I went out hunting and killed a deer - shot him in the eye at 170 yards - 
The boys killed some buffalo cows -

WEDNESDAY, April 2d 1856
Beautiful morning, one of Mr. C-'s Clark's mares foaled last night - 
We travelled about ten miles and camped at Wolf Point - 
This was the hunting ground of some free trappers several years since - one of them was killed by the Assiniboins - We found his skull

THURSDAY, April 3d 1856
Pleasant Morning - the winds westerly - 
We travelled about fourteen miles and camped near a lake in a point of timber - I went into the timber some distance but could not get a shot at anything - After dark there was an alano that one of the men was missing, after a long search and various conjectures, he was found asleep under one of our carts -

FRIDAY, April 4th 1856
Beautiful morning, very little wind - quite warm - 
We travelled about eight miles to "Riviere au Tremble" and found it too high to ford - were compelled to cross in skin boats and swim the horses, after some trouble we crossed everything and camped on the opposite bank -
Clouded up as sun set and appeared to be preparing to storm -
Mr. Wilson killed a goose and shot at some Elk and deer and missed -

SATURDAY, April 5th 1856
Very pleasant - Wind westerly  we travelled about 16 miles and camped near Frenchman Point - Is called from a Frenchman having been killed by the Assiniboins many years since - The boys saw some buffalo - killed three as we were out of meat - 
Our present camp is the old encampment of the Crows last fall - A large lodge made of trees, called a Medicine lodge is still standing

SUNDAY, April 6th, 1856
(very hot)
Beautiful morning - 
We started very early as we had a bad river to cross - We travelled about ten miles and came to the "Big Muddy" found it not very high, we crossed it with some little trouble and camped about three miles below it - I went out a short distance to hunt but killed nothing -  shot at a Grizzly - but missed on account of my horse - We passed (about three miles above The Muddy) the Fort Union outpost for the Assiniboines and learned Mr. Revais has passed in a boat from Fort Benton about one hour before we got there -

MONDAY, April 7th 1856
It sprinkled some last night and is quite cloudy this morning - 
We travelled about 14 miles, to the little "Muddy" crossed with no trouble and camped - It commenced to rain quite hard soon after we stopped - No Buffalo in sight - Killed one old Bull today - too poor to eat -

TUESDAY, April 8th 1856
The rain storm turned to snow during the no mooned night and this morning is blowing furiously and snow falling fast - 
It continued to snow during the day - I think it is as unpleasant a day as I have ever spent at this time of the year - 
It cleared up at sunset -

WEDNESDAY, April 9th 1856
Clear pleasant morning snow melting rapidly - 
We thought it too muddy to move - 
Sent out to look for the horses, Mr. Clark found nine dead, his man lost one and I lost a fine pony - 
We sent to Fort Union which is only about ten miles distant - the men returned with the news that we were encamped within six miles of a band of Assiniboines who were not very friendly - was near sunset but we immediately struck our tents and started for the fort - Mr. Wilson, Mr. Shucette and myself took the short road and reached the fort short after dark

THURSDAY, April 10th 1856
Very pleasant - Snow has mostly disappeared
The carts arrived about Three O'clock this  morning had a hard time on account of the bad roads - 
We found Mr. Kip Kipp and Mr. Denig both well - 
Mr. Clark went to the fort of Picotte and Company - 
Little news - President's message - trouble in Kansas - Evacuation of unclear +c. [[[etc.]] -

FRIDAY, April 11th 1856
Cloudy and appearance of a storm this morning - 
It commenced raining about eleven O'clock soon turning to snow, The wind raised and we had a terrible storm which lasted all day but as we are housed we don't mind it much -

SATURDAY, April 12 1856
Clear morning but cool - Thawed some during the day - enough to make it quite muddy - Mr. Clark came up and visited us - 
Mr. Wilson has concluded to continue on with Mr. Clark as he finds his health already much improved -

SUNDAY, April 13th 1856
Very pleasant - snow fast disappearing - 
A band of Assiniboine came in to trade today - poor looking set - poor men - poor horses - poor dogs - 
The day passed off quickly - 
We had some potatoes for dinner - quite a luxury after being so long without vegetables - Butter is put upon the table here also, the finest I have seen since last July -

MONDAY, April 14th 1856
Beautiful Morning - 
Mr. Clark starts on this morning
Mr. Wilson accompans him - 
They left about ten O'clock - 
It is quite muddy but drying fast - 
Assiniboins left today -

TUESDAY April 15th 1856
Strong south wind looked cloudy in the morning but soon cleared up - ground dries rapidly - 
Mr. Kipp is fearful we shall loose our horses, as there is scarcely a Spring passes without the sioux or Blackfeet taking off the horses from the fort - I do not fear it - I think the Sioux have enough to do and the Blackfeet will not disturb anything -

WEDNESDAY, April 16th 1856
Clear pleasant day quite windy - 
A Cree Chief "Broken Arm" came to the fort yesterday, he brings no news - 
Dull and lonesome no news, no indians and nothing to do -

THURSDAY, April 17th 1856
Quite pleasant - 
Nothing new - I passed the day reading and writing - The old Cree went out hunting, killed a deer

FRIDAY, April 18th 1856
Very pleasant morning and proven to be one of the pleasantest days of the season - 
The same dull monotony - 
The women of the fort had a game of ball which they appear to enjoy much but which was rather uninteresting to a bystander -

SATURDAY, April 19th 1856
The weather continues good - strong south wind - 
Bouché, hunter for the fort, went out today and killed a bull - very acceptable as we were out of fresh meat - 
Very lonely, not much to read and no other way to amuse me - 
During the evening a mad wolf came to the gates and was shot by the sentinel -

SUNDAY, April 20th 1856
Very warm until four O'clock when we were visited by the first Thunder show of the season, which cooled the air - 
Very dull - Sunday is even more so than any other day as there is no work going on - 
Discovered a fire on the other side of the river, apparently about fifteen miles above - cannot account for it -

MONDAY, April 21st 1856
Quite pleasant - 
The "broken Arm" started out to hunt deer today -
Mr. Kipp is making a boat to send below to the Rees + Gros Ventres with supplies - We have about given up looking for any express - 
The Missouri opened at this place March 26th being over a month later than at Fort Benton -

TUESDAY, April 22d 1856
Clear but Windy - 
Mr. Kipp finished his boat today - 30 ft. on the bottom - 
Will start her tomorrow
Broken Arm came i from hunting with meat - 
Rained some during the evening -

WEDNESDAY, April 23d 1856
Cloudy and cool
Mr. Kipp started his boat below - 
One of my horses and a mare belonging to Mr. Morgan ran off last night - The Cree says he saw them - sent Mr. Shucette and Mr. Morgan to hunt them -

THURSDAY, April 24 1856
Shucette and Morgan returned without the horses - 
It commenced raining about 10 O'clock and continued throughout the day and evening - wind blowing very hard from South east -

FRIDAY, April 25 1856
Pleasant morning, cleared off soon after sun rise - 
Snowed some during the night - Started Shucette and Morgan after the horses with an indian to show the spot where they went - 
The grass is springing up rapidly, horses live well -

SATURDAY, April 26 1856
Beautiful morning - 
This was probably the finest day of the spring - Bouché came in from hunting with several deer - the indian, also returned, who accompanied Shucette - 
Shucette, having lost Morgan, returned in the evening - no horses - 
Mr Morgan also returned with same story -

SUNDAY, April 27th 1856
Very pleasant - 
Shucette + Morgan started to look for the horses again but they have been lost so long that the case is almost hopeless - 
Sunday and every one idle and complaining of the dullness -

MONDAY, April 28th 1856
Another very pleasant day - 
Mr. Kipp the commander or Bourgeois as he is called has a saw mill (horse power) which troubles him much as he can not make it go right - he continues to saw some though and is preparing to repair the pickets to the fort - 
Bouché with two carts started hunting -

TUESDAY, April 29th 1856
Pleasant day - 
Shucette + Morgan returned from hunting the horses - could not find them 
Mr. Riter the clerk (2°) of the fort is getting ready for planting a garden -

WEDNESDAY, April 3.th 1856
Weather continues pleasant - 
Bouche returned with meat of three cows and one bull - cows very poor - 
We occasionally see fires about - suppose them to have been kindled by "enemies" as all indians are called here - except Assiniboins -

THURSDAY, May 1st 1856
Very pleasant May day - I walked out a short distance saw some early flowers on the prairie - grass about three inches high - Timber not changed nothing green except the prairies and the people who will live in such a country - 
Mr. Riter finishes his garden today -

FRIDAY, May 2d 1856
Quite pleasant - 
Mr. Picotte with three boats loaded with furs passed here today and landed at the fort below (two miles) belonging to Picotte + co. - 
Shucette went down - no news from above of any importance - Twenty two days "en route" - vegetation much more forward there when he left than it is here at present - 
Blood indians out to war -

SATURDAY, May 3d 1856
Cloudy - 
I visited Mr. Picotte he tells me that he will start on this afternoon and thinks he will reach St Louis in 25 or 30 days - 
Report Buffalo plenty above - 
The river has been rising here for one or two days - Mr. Kipp arranged a fish trap in the river it has been used with much success heretofor -

SUNDAY, May 4th 1856
Cloudy morning appearance of rain but passed off only a few drops falling - 
We have an alarm occasionally, of indians, but have not yet seen any enemies - 
I discovered some one in the point above the fort and the excitement was great for a few minutes, when we discovered that it was Bouché -

MONDAY, May 5th 1856
Cloudy and cool - 
The wind has been south east for several days and it is usually accompanied by rain in this country but it seems to be a failure at present - 
An Assiniboine came to the fort - had stolen a woman from camp and ran away with her - says he is going to the Gros Ventres of the prairie

TUESDAY, May 6th 1856
Very pleasant - 
We raised the fish trap this morning but found nothing but two shiners - 
Bouché with two carts started to hunt Shucette went with him - 
Mr. Morgan started out to hunt for deer but lost his knife and returned - 
Broken Arm started with Bouché killed a cow and returned -

WEDNESDAY, May 7th 1856
Beautiful Morning - Looked at the fish trap found one fish, nondescript, half catfish and half Eel - 
Bouché returned from hunting with cows + bulls - 
Morgan went out again today -

THURSDAY, May 8th 1856
Very pleasant -
Bouche + Shucette went out again but found nothing - 
I rode out four of five miles into the hills, saw no game - found it quite warm -
Morgans horse came home about noon, but no sign of him, don't know whether he has been killed by the indians or not

FRIDAY, May 9th 1856
Beautiful day - 
Morgan returned in the night - his horse had ran away from him - he caught one beaver - 
Quite warm - 
There is no great variety here in the amusements - we read over old books that every one has read two or three times at least - get tired - and talk of the probability of an express coming up

SATURDAY, May 10th 1856
Another still pleasant morning - The weather was quite warm until after dinner when is clouded over, the wind sprang up from the north with a few drops of rain and it was even cool enough for a fire - 
Mr. Morgan went out again to hunt - returned with some ducks and geese - 
The trees are just beginning to look green -

SUNDAY, May 11th 1856
Cool, clear morning - proved to be a very pleasant day - Water rising rapidly
Mr. Denig's son went out and came back with a report of indians - great excitement for a short time - horses caught up and saddled - men charging across the plains and disappearing over the hills - All soon returned having found the Indians + five friendly Assiniboins - they bring the news of three lodges of their people destroyed by the Sioux - 8 men and 9 women + children

MONDAY, May 12th 1856
Cool morning, wind strong from the south
Men pressing packs - pressed 120 packs today - 
Mr. Kipp sent out the hunters again for meat with two carts - 
River is still rising slowly - 
It is quite lonely especially in the evening, as then the men retire each one to his own room and I being the only one unmarried am left alone -

TUESDAY, May 13th 1856
Pleasant morning - 
Pressing of packs still going on - 
Mr. Denigs son took some of the women of the fort out to the hills to dig Pomme blanche they returned with a few -
The hunters came in with the meat of five cows -  
"Broken Arm" who had started beaver hunting returned, afraid of the Sioux -

WEDNESDAY, May 14th 1856
Cool, unpleasant morning, small shower last night - 
No change - Mr. Kipp attending to the saw mill - Mr. Denig doing nothing, +c. +c. etc. etc. -
I am perfectly disgusted with this country and shall be pleased when the day comes that I can start for St Paul - 
It is perhaps improper to allow such a feeling to take possession of one, as I have experienced nothing but kindness from the traders and their employes - but I can't help it

THURSDAY, May 15th 1856
Cool, clear, windy morning - 
I have a vest which I wore at St Paul last winter, a year, also last winter at the Blackfeet - today having it on I discovered a hole in one of the pockets, found in it a 3 $. bill on Oneida bank and 1 $. Borup + banks - They look like old friends as it is long since I have seen any paper money - 
I rode out to the hills saw nothing but found the mosquitoes more plenty than I have ever seen them on the high prairie

FRIDAY, May 16th 1856
Very foggy, but cleared off soon after sunrise - warm beautiful day - 
Mr. Kipp finished sawing today for the present - he has been preparing to unclear the pickets on the backside of the fort and has timber enough sawed for this purpose -
River rising very slowly -

SATURDAY, May 17th 1856
Pleasant, but windy
We have had no sucess thus far in catching fish in the fish trap - 
River is still rising - think this is the big rise, consequently Mr. Dawson will be here from Fort Benton in a few days - 
Assiniboin Indian came to the fort today and says he saw a large party of Blackfeet above here - probably a lie -

SUNDAY, May 18th 1856 
Very beautiful morning 
We had waffles for breakfast - very good for an Indian country - also asparagus and ice cream for dinner - quite a change from my diet last winter - 
The thermometer at 4 1/2 O'clock stood at 92° above zero - warmest day of the season - 
Mr. Morgan and Broken Arm started on a hunt today - 
River still rising -

MONDAY, May 19th 1856
Fine Morning - Winds strong from the south - 
Thermometer at 90 at 12 O'clock - 
Mr. Kipp commenced pulling down and repairing pickets - 
Bouché started for meat with two carts - 
Some thunder showers passed around - 
I was reading a journal which was kept at this fort for many years and find the river closes commonly from the 6th to the 9th of November and opens about the 10th of April -

TUESDAY, May 20th 1856
Cloudy at sun rise and appearance of a heavy storm but it soon cleared off with a strong south wind and day very hot - Thermometer at 92 at One O'clock - 
Bouche returned with meat of four cows - 
River at a stand - 
Expecting some news from the Blackfeet country daily -

WENESDAY, May 21st 1856
Very pleasant morning strong west wind - 
The watchman says he heard two guns last evening, about eleven O'clock in the point below - doubtful! - 
Clouded over about noon and rained a very little, the weather much cooler, Thermometer at 62 - 30 degrees lower that yesterday - 
Hailed in the afternoon very little -

THURSDAY, May 22d 1856
Very beautiful morning cool night but bids fair to be the hottest day of the season - 
I crossed the river to try to catch some fish as we can catch none in the trap - I caught one and returned to dinner - 
After dinner I crossed again and returned at eight with ten fine cat fish - 
Quite warm during the day -

FRIDAY, May 23d 1856
Cloudy and a little cooler - 
Some of the squaws went visiting to the other fort - came back with a report that two hunters who were over on the yellow store had see indians and ran home - 
if true we will hear more soon - 
It often clouds over now and looks like rain but does not - everything very dry and rain is much needed - 
Mr. Riter visited his garden and found potatoes and corn up -

SATURDAY, May 24th 1856
Cloudy, cool and looks stormy - wind from the north east - 
Cleared up and remained so until near sunset, when it again clouded over and we had a light shower in the evening accompanied with much thunder and lightning - 
An Assiniboin arrived from the north - 
No news -

SUNDAY, May 25th 1856
Clear morning - wind strong from the east - somewhat cooler 
About noon two buffalo were seen just above the fort - great excitement! - 
Men running with guns +c. etc. - They killed both - one cow and one bull - The meat was divided among the families in the fort -

MONDAY, May 26th 1856
Cloudy and cool - 
It rained some during the night - 
The men started hunting with two carts - killed four cows and one bull and returned at 5 O'clock -
The long looked for express arrived from St Louis today but by some mistake my letters did not come - The Steamboat was to leave the 15th of May for this place so we will get all the news about the 20th of June probably -

TUESDAY, May 27th 1856
Beautiful, calm morning - 
Mr. Dawson will make a fine run today -
I went across the river, to fish, after dinner and caught as many as I could carry - 
Six Assiniboins came in from a camp of one hundred lodges about thirty or forty miles below here - bring no news except buffalo very plenty -

WEDNESDAY, May 28th 1856
Very pleasant - 
Mr. Kipp sent most of the men to the timber about twelve miles above to get out logs for plank to build boats - 
- Thermometer 94° in the shade . -
Boats from Blackfoot, Mr. Dawson in charge, arrived with 1500 pelts robes - 
Families arrived also, with band of horses from same place - 
Report everything quiet above -

THURSDAY, May 29th 1856
Beautiful morning - 
Mr. D- Dawson + Mr Denig busy settling accounts +c etc - Men are unloading boat and loading another preparatory to starting on - 
Baptiste Champagne who came down with the horses is very sick - 
The men from above finished preparations and the boats are all ready to start on tomorrow - 
A warm day clouded over at night

FRIDAY, May 30th 1856
Very fine morning, but wind blew too hard for the boats to leave - It rained some in the night - 
Mr. Morgan and Indian returned from their hunt with about twenty beaver - 
I shall send tomorrow for my horse that was lost - the people who came down found the one that was with him when he ran off and he can not be far from there -

MAY 31st 1856
Beautiful, still morning - 
The boats left before I was up - 
Mr. May started back to Fort Benton with a waggon load of goods - 
Shucette + Chambers start to hunt my horse and 13 others that were lost or stolen from the barn on their way down - 
Man arrived, at the other fort, from the Blackfeet - he is a half breed going to Red River - brings but little news - the Assiniboins have stolen some horses from the Gros Ventres -

SUNDAY, June 1st 1856
Very pleasant - We had a very heavy thunder storm last night but very little rain - 
Sunday, passed as usual nothing stirring - 
A crow squaw arrived at the other fort last night -  she was formerly the wife of a white man by the name of Meldrum and came hundreds of miles down the Yellow Stone river alone in a skin canoe to join her husband - quite romantic!!! -

MONDAY, June 2d 1856
Pleasant Morning but soon clouded over
We had another very heavy thunder storm last night accompanied by a good deal of rain
It rained some during the afternoon - 
-Mr Kipp's man returned today with a raft of log - 
Another heavy storm during the evening.

TUESDAY, June 3d 1856
Cloudy and cool - Mr. Morgan and Mr. Bird started to trap for beaver - It rained nearly all day - We had lettuce for dinner - 

Wednesday June 4th 1856
Quite pleasant - I was taken with a severe sore throat this forenoon, at tea time unable to eat any thing - Mr. Kipp commenced sawing plank for boats - 

Thursday June 5th 1856
Very pleasant day - About 2 O'clock great alarm! Men + women running!  Enemies! +c. etc. All moonshine - it proved to be 10 or 15 women on horseback who had been after Pomme blanch
Some Crees came in from the north - traded a few robes and a white calf skin - Finis. 
End of this journal
